Award.AwardTitle: SusChEM: Copper-Catalyzed Radical Reactions of Nitroso Compounds for the Synthesis of Carbon-Nitrogen Bonds
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Catalysis Program of the Chemistry Division supports the project by Professor Read de Alaniz. Professor Read de Alaniz is a faculty member in the Department of Chemistry at University of California Santa Barbara (UCSB). He is developing new strategies for the direct incorporation of nitrogen and oxygen atoms into structurally diverse molecules using earth abundant metals. The goal of this research is to develop a general and versatile strategy to expedite the discovery of therapeutic agents. The molecular diversity of nitrogen containing therapeutic agents and the strong influence nitrogen substituents have on both pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics mandates the development of new methodologies for installing these functional groups into small therapeutic organic molecules. In addition, the methodology has potential applications in material science, as well as for the construct of agrochemical compounds. The project is well suited for the education of scientists at all levels. The educational plan includes training of underrepresented groups in outstanding professional development and research training programs at UCSB's California NanoSystems Institute and Materials Research Lab (notably the RISE, SIMS, UC LEADS, CAMP, and MARC programs), as well as developing a new multi-layered mentoring program for graduate students.

While the value of amines and the synthetic utility of radical reactions are well-established, exploration of the strategy for constructing carbon (C) - nitrogen (N) and C-oxygen (O) bonds by merging radical reactions with nitroso compounds is almost completely unknown. Through these studies, new opportunities in C-N bond-forming reactions that are mild, functional group tolerant, and use earth abundant copper are under development. These new transformations reduce the number of synthetic steps required to access nitrogen containing molecules that are otherwise difficult to prepare. The transformations also give chemists access to new synthetic bond disconnections. Specifically, the goals of the proposed work are: 1) extend the scope of the recently developed copper-catalyzed radical addition with nitroso compounds to include heterocycles, benzyl bromides and alpha-bromo nitriles; 2) develop the reaction with commercially available aryl and heteroaryltrifluoroborates using nitrite salts to generate the nitroso reagent in situ; 3) apply this strategy to the concise total synthesis of pyrroloindoline alkaloid natural products; 4) develop a new intramolecular radical based N-O transfer process that provides spatial control of the nitrogen and oxygen heteroatoms over a range of architectures. Professor Read de Alaniz's group is well positioned to provide the highest level of education and training for students underrepresented in science. Outreach activities involving a new multi-layered mentoring program are part of the project.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The enormous molecular diversity of nitrogen and oxygen containing therapeutic agents and the strong influence the nitrogen substituent has on both pharmacokinetics and pharmacodynamics, mandates the development of new strategies for installing nitrogen and oxygen functionality into small therapeutic organic molecules. Our group has made significant contributions that have advanced carbon-nitrogen and carbon-oxygen bond-forming processes using nitroso chemistry. One of the most significant challenge in this area is the construction of sterically hindered carbon–nitrogen bonds. To address this challenge and to help open a new direction for nitroso chemistry in route to a general amination strategy for organic synthesis, our group developed an operationally simple method for direct construction of sterically hindered anilines. The new process can be conducted at room temperature, uses readily available starting materials, employs earth abundant copper salt as a catalyst and is highly functional-group-tolerant. As a demonstration of the power of this approach, we were able to use our new strategy toward the total synthesis of chetomin and asperazine A, two natural products with exceptional medicinal potential that are lacking a robust synthetic access. Chetomin is a known HIF 1α inhibitor and has been demonstrated as a potential therapy for solid tumor derived cancers, however there are currently no known total synthesis of this biologically active molecule.   

To further expand the synthetic utility of this methodology we have also developed a three-component coupling of electron-rich arylboronic acids with t-butyl nitrite and a range of alkyl halides. In this case, the N-aryl and sterically hindered C–N bond are formed in a single protocol, again using mild reaction conditions, earth abundant copper salts and commercially available reagents. Furthermore, we developed a new methodology to introduce nitrogen and oxygen functionality into organic molecules with spatial control. This approach enables access to N–O heterocycles that range from small 5-membered rings up to large 19-membered rings. Prior to this work, N–O heterocycle synthesis was limited to 3-6 membered ring systems. In summary, using earth abundant copper salts and a new synthetic platform that relies on radical transformations with nitroso compounds we have been able to provide chemists with a new approach to bioactive molecules that does not rely on precious metals.

Broader Impacts: In addition to what we perceive as the useful science that has emerged from this grant, broader impacts include recruiting and retention of underrepresented minority students and women at both the undergraduate and graduate student level, as well as extensive outreach contributions. Highlights of diversity activities during this funding period are outlined below.

  • Director of the NSF Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation (LSAMP) Bridges to Doctorate (BD) Program (2017-2022). The NSF BD program supports 12 PhD students underrepresented in science and engineering from 10 different STEM departments. As director of the BD program, I provide the general oversight for the 5-year program.
  • Faculty advisor for SACNAS Chapter at UCSB. In collaboration with the BD Program, SACNAS members organized a workshop at the 2019 SACNAS National Conference titled “Being Your Authentic Self in Grad School”.
  • Faculty outreach coordinator for NSF MRSEC at UCSB (2012–2020). In this role, I have been instrumental in the UCSB-UTEP PREM (Partnership for Research and Education in Materials) Program, serving as both faculty outreach coordinator and faculty researcher/mentor. The mission of this program is to broaden the participation and advanced degree attainment of underrepresented minorities, primarily Hispanic students, in material science and engineering.
  • Advisory board for diversity – UCSB Graduate Division Dean Carol Genetti (2018-20). In this role, I have helped advise Graduate Division on diversity effort.
  • External Advisory Board for the NSF PREM between New Mexico Highlands University and Ohio State University (2018). Helped evaluate the program.
  • My research group is actively involved in training undergraduate students. As part of my involvement I have given well over ten presentations in past three years about diversity in science and mentored 17 undergraduate research students. Of these 11 were female (65%) and 7 were URM (41%), 14 have graduated. Moreover, most have gone on to graduate school or are currently employed in STEM. For example, Shelby Shankel (graduated 2018, PhD program Cornell, Goldwater Scholar), Ngan Nguyen (graduated 2018, PhD/MD program University of Michigan), Jose Delgado (graduated 2020, PhD program UC San Diego), Sara El-Arid (graduated 2020, PhD program Boston College), Victoria Rubio (graduated 2020, PhD program UC Los Angeles), Jesus Guillen Campos (graduated 2020, PhD program UC Santa Barbara), Gustavo Alcantara (graduated 2020 (UTEP PREM), PhD program UC Santa Barbara), Jessica Lopez Lara (partially supported by this grant, graduated 2020 (UC Merced part of UC LEADS), PhD program UC Santa Barbara), Zi-Jie Liu (graduated 2020, PhD program MIT), Alexandria Bernal (graduated 2019, NIH IRTA program), Helena Steffens (partially supported by this grant, graduated 2019, J&J), Mina Faust (graduated 2019, Apeel Sciences), and Luis Gonzalez (partially supported by this grant, graduated 2020, Materia).
